metadata.name: NTSB Incident Event Graphs for Endogenous Pivot Validation
metadata.description: Real-world incident reports mapped to Rhun-compatible event graphs. Each incident has timestamped events, actor assignments, severity weights, and a ground-truth pivot (probable cause / turning point). Designed to validate the validity mirage under progressive compression.
metadata.source: NTSB accident reports (public domain), supplemented with tech postmortems

schema.events: Timestamped incident events with actor, weight, and phase label
schema.pivot_ground_truth: The event identified as probable cause / turning point by investigators
schema.competing_pivots: Alternative high-weight events that a compressor might substitute

weight_rubric.description: Weights 1-100 assigned by causal centrality: how many downstream consequences depend on this event
weight_rubric.90-100: Root cause / probable cause event (the pivot)
weight_rubric.70-89: Major contributing factor or critical failure in causal chain
weight_rubric.30-49: Relevant context or minor contributing factor

incidents.title: Southwest Airlines Flight 1380 — Engine Failure and Depressurization
incidents.summary: Fan blade fatigue fracture caused engine failure, cowl separation struck fuselage, cabin window departed, one fatality.
incidents.probable_cause: Low-cycle fatigue crack in dovetail of fan blade No. 13 causing blade separation and cowl fragment impact on fuselage window.

events.desc: Fan blade set last overhauled (Nov 2012) with visual and fluorescent penetrant inspections
CFM56-7B engine and 737-700 certificated (1996-97) using then-current analytical tools
Six fan blade relubrications with visual inspections — crack not detected
Low-cycle fatigue crack initiates in fan blade 13 dovetail due to higher-than-expected stresses
SWA Flight 3472 (Aug 2016) — similar fan blade fracture on same engine type, prompting new eddy current inspection AD
Crack most likely not detectable by fluorescent penetrant inspection at last overhaul
Flight 1380 departs LaGuardia for Dallas Love Field with 144 passengers and 5 crew
Fan blade 13 separates in flight at FL320 — impacts fan case at critical structural location
Fan cowl structural failure — loads through radial restraint fitting cause cowl separation
Inboard fan cowl aft latch keeper strikes fuselage near row 14 window — window departs
Rapid cabin depressurization — one passenger fatally injured
Flight crew conducts emergency descent and diverts to Philadelphia
NTSB issues 7 safety recommendations including fan cowl redesign

incidents.mirage_scenario: Under compression, if e04 (crack initiation) and e05-e06 (inspection history) are summarized away, a model may reattribute the pivot to e09 (cowl failure) or e10 (window departure) — both are dramatic but are consequences, not the root cause.

incidents.title: Atlas Air Flight 3591 — Rapid Descent and Crash into Trinity Bay
incidents.summary: First officer's inappropriate response to inadvertent go-around activation led to spatial disorientation and unrecoverable dive. All 3 crew killed.
incidents.probable_cause: First officer's inappropriate response to inadvertent go-around mode activation, leading to spatial disorientation and nose-down inputs.

events.desc: FO has history of training performance deficiencies at multiple prior employers
FO deliberately conceals performance history on resumes and applications to Atlas Air
FAA fails to implement robust pilot records database per 2010 congressional mandate
Atlas relies on designated agents rather than flight operations experts to review pilot records
FO demonstrates maladaptive stress response and impulsive reactions in training scenarios
Cargo flight departs Miami for Houston with captain, FO, and jumpseat pilot
Flight encounters leading edge of cold front with light turbulence at ~6,300 ft during descent
Go-around mode inadvertently activated — likely by FO's wrist/watch contacting switch in turbulence
FO experiences somatogravic illusion from acceleration, makes nose-down elevator inputs placing aircraft in steep dive
Captain fails to adequately monitor flightpath and does not assume positive control in time
Only 32 seconds between go-around activation and ground impact
Aircraft crashes into shallow marsh in Trinity Bay — all three crew killed, aircraft destroyed

incidents.mirage_scenario: Compression may merge e01-e05 (FO background) into a generic 'crew issues' summary, making e08 (go-around activation) appear to be the pivot. This substitutes a triggering event for the actual root cause (the FO's inappropriate response to that trigger).

incidents.title: Island Express Helicopters — Calabasas Terrain Impact
incidents.summary: Helicopter pilot continued VFR flight into IMC, experienced spatial disorientation, lost control. 9 fatalities including pilot.
incidents.probable_cause: Pilot's decision to continue VFR flight into instrument meteorological conditions, resulting in spatial disorientation and loss of control.

events.desc: Dense fog and low clouds throughout LA basin — Van Nuys reports 1,100 ft overcast, 2.5 mi visibility
Island Express not certified for IFR operations — VFR only
Pilot deems conditions 'OK' in text messages despite fog warnings
Helicopter departs John Wayne Airport with pilot and 8 passengers
Pilot requests and receives Special VFR clearance — circles for 12 minutes awaiting approval
Pilot flies at 400-600 ft AGL below cloud layer, navigating visually along terrain
Self-induced pressure to complete flight for high-profile client affects decision-making
Plan continuation bias — pilot continues despite deteriorating weather and rising terrain
Pilot continues VFR into IMC — initiates climb to get above cloud layers near rising terrain over US-101
Pilot enters clouds, experiences spatial disorientation — believes climbing when actually descending
Pilot reports 'climbing to four thousand' to ATC — aircraft actually descending at ~4,000 fpm
Helicopter impacts hillside at >184 mph in left-banked descent — all 9 aboard killed

incidents.mirage_scenario: Under compression, the gradual decision chain (e05-e08) gets collapsed. A model may identify e10 (spatial disorientation) as the pivot rather than e09 (the decision to continue into IMC), substituting the proximate physiological failure for the causal decision.

incidents.title: US Airways Flight 1549 — Ditching in Hudson River (Miracle on the Hudson)
incidents.summary: Both engines lost thrust after ingesting Canada geese during climb. Crew ditched in Hudson River. All 155 survived.
incidents.probable_cause: Dual-engine thrust loss due to bird ingestion from encounter with flock of Canada geese at ~2,800 ft during climb.

events.desc: Flock of Canada geese present at ~2,800 ft in departure corridor from LaGuardia
A320 departs LaGuardia Runway 4 with 150 passengers and 5 crew
Aircraft climbing normally through ~2,800 ft AGL about 90 seconds after takeoff
Both engines ingest multiple Canada geese — dual engine thrust loss
Captain Sullenberger takes controls, assesses options — determines cannot reach any airport
FO Skiles runs dual-engine failure checklist — attempts engine restart unsuccessful
Captain decides to ditch in Hudson River — the only viable option within glide range
Successful water landing at ~150 kt — aircraft remains intact and afloat
Ferry boats and emergency responders rescue all 155 occupants
NTSB recommendations on bird-strike standards and engine ingestion certification

incidents.mirage_scenario: This incident has strong resolution events (the heroic ditching). Under compression, e04 may be summarized as 'engine failure' and the narrative weight shifts to e07 (decision to ditch) as the apparent pivot — replacing the causal event with the response.

incidents.title: Ameristar Air Cargo Flight 9363 — Runway Overrun During Rejected Takeoff
incidents.summary: MD-83 crew rejected takeoff at high speed after captain observed abnormal left roll, overran runway. No fatalities, substantial damage.
incidents.probable_cause: Flight crew's decision to reject the takeoff after the airplane had exceeded V1 speed, which resulted in a runway overrun.

events.desc: Left outboard leading edge slat actuator had pre-existing internal corrosion limiting extension
Maintenance procedures did not detect slat actuator degradation
MD-83 cargo flight prepares for departure from Willow Run Airport, Ypsilanti, Michigan
During takeoff roll, left outboard slat fails to extend fully — creates asymmetric lift
Captain perceives abnormal left roll tendency during takeoff acceleration
Aircraft exceeds V1 (takeoff decision speed) — standard procedure requires continuing takeoff
Captain decides to reject takeoff above V1 speed — initiates high-speed abort
Deceleration insufficient for remaining runway — aircraft overruns at ~60 kt
Aircraft crosses airport perimeter road and stops in field — substantial damage, no injuries
NTSB recommends improved slat inspection procedures and rejected takeoff training

incidents.mirage_scenario: The slat malfunction (e04) is a compelling alternative pivot. Under compression, if the V1 exceedance context (e06) is lost, a model may reattribute the accident to the slat failure rather than the crew's decision to reject above V1.

incidents.title: PenAir Flight 3296 — Runway Overrun During Landing at Unalaska
incidents.summary: Saab 2000 overran runway during landing at Dutch Harbor in marginal weather. Crew did not execute go-around despite unstabilized approach.
incidents.probable_cause: Flight crew's continuation of an unstabilized approach and failure to execute a go-around.

events.desc: Challenging approach to Unalaska — short runway, mountainous terrain, marginal weather
Company procedures specify stabilized approach criteria and go-around requirements
Low ceilings, gusty crosswinds, and reduced visibility at Dutch Harbor airport
Approach becomes unstabilized — aircraft above glidepath and faster than target speed
Multiple stabilized approach criteria exceeded — go-around warranted per company SOP
Captain decides to continue approach despite exceeding stabilized approach criteria
Crew continues unstabilized approach to landing — fails to execute mandatory go-around
Aircraft touches down long and fast — insufficient runway remaining to stop
Aircraft overruns runway, goes down embankment — 1 passenger fatality, multiple injuries
NTSB recommends enhanced go-around decision support and unstabilized approach monitoring

incidents.mirage_scenario: Weather (e03) and the landing itself (e08) are salient compression targets. If the progressive decision chain (e04-e06) is lost, the model may pivot to 'bad weather caused crash' rather than 'crew continued when they should have gone around.'

incidents.title: Beech King Air 65-A90 — Parachute Jump Flight Crash at Mokuleia
incidents.summary: King Air crashed on takeoff from Dillingham Airfield during skydiving operations. Engine lost power, aircraft stalled. 11 fatalities.
incidents.probable_cause: Pilot's decision to take off with an engine that was not producing full power, leading to loss of control during climb.

events.desc: Left engine had pre-existing condition — not producing rated power due to fuel system issue
Skydiving operation at Dillingham Airfield — short runway near ocean with obstructions
Pilot had made multiple flights that day — earlier flights showed signs of reduced left engine power
Aircraft loaded with pilot and 10 skydivers — near maximum weight for conditions
Pilot elects to take off despite indications of degraded left engine performance
Left engine power insufficient for climb — aircraft unable to maintain altitude after takeoff
Pilot loses control — aircraft stalls at low altitude
Aircraft crashes near runway — fire ensues, all 11 aboard killed
NTSB recommendations on parachute jump operation oversight and engine health monitoring

incidents.mirage_scenario: The engine condition (e01) is the intuitive 'mechanical failure' narrative. Compression may drop e03 (prior flights showing reduced power) and reattribute to 'engine failure' rather than 'pilot decision to fly with known degraded engine.'

incidents.title: Heart of Texas Hot Air Balloon — Power Line Strike at Lockhart
incidents.summary: Hot air balloon struck power lines during descent in morning haze. Fire and crash killed all 16 aboard. Pilot had impairing medications.
incidents.probable_cause: Pilot's decision to fly into deteriorating weather conditions and his impairment from medications.

events.desc: Pilot was taking multiple impairing medications including opioids, benzodiazepines, and antihistamines
Pilot had history of DWI convictions — FAA unaware due to inadequate medical screening
Balloon pilots not required to hold medical certificate — no drug screening requirement
Morning fog and haze reducing visibility — conditions deteriorating during flight
Pilot continues flight into area with power lines despite reduced visibility
Pilot's impaired judgment and decision-making leads to continued flight into hazardous conditions
Balloon contacts high-voltage power lines during descent — fire erupts
Balloon envelope separates from gondola — crashes into field, all 16 killed
NTSB recommends FAA require medical certification for balloon pilots

incidents.mirage_scenario: The power line strike (e07) is the most visually dramatic event. Under compression, the medication impairment chain (e01-e02) is easily lost, shifting the narrative from 'impaired pilot made bad decisions' to 'balloon hit power lines.'

incidents.title: Delta Air Lines Flight 1086 — Runway Excursion at LaGuardia
incidents.summary: MD-88 landed during snowstorm at LaGuardia, left runway, penetrated airport fence, stopped on embankment over Flushing Bay.
incidents.probable_cause: Captain's failure to maintain directional control during landing in snow, and his delayed use of reverse thrust.

events.desc: Heavy snowfall at LaGuardia — runway contaminated with snow and reduced braking action
Runway friction reports indicated deteriorating conditions — 'fair' braking reported
Flight crew briefs approach and landing — discusses contaminated runway procedures
Aircraft approaches runway 13 — crosswind from left
Aircraft touches down with left drift — captain's rudder input insufficient to track centerline
Captain fails to maintain directional control and delays reverse thrust application
Aircraft departs left side of runway — travels across grass and through perimeter fence
Aircraft stops on embankment feet from Flushing Bay — 24 minor injuries, substantial damage
NTSB recommends improved contaminated runway training and braking action reports

incidents.mirage_scenario: Weather (e01) is the obvious alternative pivot. Compression tends to merge the crew's specific directional control failure (e06) into the weather narrative, shifting blame from pilot technique to conditions.

incidents.title: Execuflight Flight 1526 — Crash During Nonprecision Approach
incidents.summary: HS 125 crashed short of Akron airport during nonprecision approach in IMC. Crew descended below MDA without required visual references.
incidents.probable_cause: Flight crew's continuation of approach below minimum descent altitude without required visual references, and their failure to execute a missed approach.

events.desc: Execuflight had history of FAA oversight concerns — inadequate training program for Part 135
Captain's training records showed deficiencies — company did not adequately address them
IMC conditions at Akron-Fulton airport — low ceilings requiring instrument approach
Crew conducts VOR approach with high workload — multiple altitude and configuration deviations
Aircraft reaches minimum descent altitude — required visual references not acquired
Missed approach criteria met — crew required to execute missed approach per regulations
Crew continues descent below MDA without visual references — does not execute missed approach
Aircraft impacts terrain and apartment building short of runway — both crew and 1 occupant killed
NTSB cites inadequate FAA oversight of Execuflight and recommends enhanced Part 135 surveillance

incidents.mirage_scenario: The operator's systemic issues (e01-e02) and the terrain impact (e08) compete for pivot status. Compression may drop the specific MDA decision chain (e05-e06) and reframe as either 'company was unsafe' or 'aircraft hit building' rather than the crew's specific decision to continue below minimums.

incidents.title: Embraer EMB-500 — Aerodynamic Stall on Approach at Gaithersburg
incidents.summary: Pilot lost control during instrument approach in icing conditions. Aircraft stalled and impacted residential area. All 3 aboard plus 2 on ground killed.
incidents.probable_cause: Pilot's failure to maintain adequate airspeed during approach, leading to aerodynamic stall. Ice contamination was a contributing factor.

events.desc: Moderate icing conditions reported along approach path — freezing precipitation
Pilot had limited experience in actual icing conditions in Phenom 100
Ice accumulation on airframe — wing deicing system engaged but ice accretion affects stall margin
Pilot configures for approach — extends flaps and slows aircraft
Pilot allows airspeed to decrease below safe approach speed in icing conditions — fails to maintain adequate margin above stall
Aircraft enters aerodynamic stall at low altitude — loss of control
Aircraft impacts residential area — 3 aboard and 2 on ground killed
NTSB recommends enhanced icing awareness training for light jet pilots

incidents.mirage_scenario: Icing (e01, e03) provides a strong competing narrative. Compression may drop the specific airspeed management failure (e05) and attribute the accident to 'ice brought down the plane' rather than 'pilot didn't fly fast enough in icing conditions.'

incidents.title: Knight Capital Group — Algorithmic Trading System Failure
incidents.summary: Software deployment error activated obsolete test code, causing $440M loss in 45 minutes of erratic trading. Company forced into acquisition.
incidents.probable_cause: Deployment of new SMARS code to 7 of 8 servers left one server running obsolete Power Peg code, which executed millions of unintended trades.

events.desc: Legacy Power Peg code remains on servers — repurposed flag used by new RLP code
No automated deployment verification system — manual process for code rollout
NYSE announces new Retail Liquidity Program starting Aug 1 — Knight develops new SMARS code
Technician deploys new SMARS code to 7 of 8 servers — 8th server retains obsolete Power Peg code
No deployment verification run — mismatch between servers goes undetected
Market opens Aug 1 — RLP orders route to all 8 SMARS servers
Server 8 receives RLP orders, activates dormant Power Peg code — begins executing millions of unintended trades
Knight accumulates massive unintended positions — $440M loss in 45 minutes
Kill switch not available — 45 minutes to identify and stop the errant server
Knight Capital forced into emergency acquisition by Getco to avoid bankruptcy

incidents.mirage_scenario: The deployment error (e04) is the intuitive 'human error' pivot. Under compression, the specific server-level activation mechanism (e07) gets merged with the deployment, losing the distinction between 'incomplete deployment' and 'dormant code activated by new order routing.'
